title: Canadian Association of Radiologists and Osteoporosis Canada (CAROC) System
description: Assesses 10-year absolute fracture risk based on age, sex, femoral neck T-score, and clinical risk factors. Stratifies patients into low (<10%), moderate (10-20%), or high (>20%) risk categories for major osteoporotic fractures.

parameters.name: femoral_neck_t_score
parameters.description: Femoral neck T-score from DXA scan. Negative values indicate bone loss relative to young adult reference

parameters.name: fragility_fracture
parameters.description: History of fragility fracture after age 40 (fracture from fall at standing height or less)

parameters.name: glucocorticoid_use
parameters.description: Current systemic glucocorticoid therapy for ≥3 months in the past year at prednisone-equivalent dose ≥7.5 mg daily

ranges.interpretation: Low risk of major osteoporotic fracture over the next 10 years. General lifestyle recommendations including adequate calcium (1200 mg/day), vitamin D (800-2000 IU/day), regular weight-bearing exercise, fall prevention, and avoidance of smoking and excessive alcohol. Repeat BMD in 3-5 years or as clinically indicated.

Moderate risk of major osteoporotic fracture over the next 10 years. Consider pharmacologic therapy based on patient preferences, additional risk factors, and BMD trends. Ensure adequate calcium and vitamin D supplementation. Implement fall prevention strategies. Consider vertebral imaging if height loss or back pain present.

High risk of major osteoporotic fracture over the next 10 years. Pharmacologic therapy strongly recommended unless contraindicated. First-line options include bisphosphonates, denosumab, or other approved therapies. Ensure adequate calcium and vitamin D. Implement comprehensive fracture prevention strategies including fall prevention and exercise programs.

references: Siminoski K, Leslie WD, Frame H, Hodsman A, Josse RG, Khan A, et al. Recommendations for bone mineral density reporting in Canada: a shift to absolute fracture risk assessment. J Clin Densitom. 2007 Apr-Jun;10(2):120-3. doi: 10.1016/j.jocd.2007.01.001.

Leslie WD, Berger C, Langsetmo L, Lix LM, Adachi JD, Hanley DA, et al. Construction and validation of a simplified fracture risk assessment tool for Canadian women and men: results from the CaMos and Manitoba cohorts. Osteoporos Int. 2011 Jun;22(6):1873-83. doi: 10.1007/s00198-010-1445-5.

Papaioannou A, Morin S, Cheung AM, Atkinson S, Brown JP, Feldman S, et al. 2010 clinical practice guidelines for the diagnosis and management of osteoporosis in Canada: summary. CMAJ. 2010 Nov 23;182(17):1864-73. doi: 10.1503/cmaj.100771.
formula: Risk categorization based on age-specific and sex-specific femoral neck T-score thresholds, with clinical risk factors elevating the risk category
notes: CAROC is a simplified tool that captures major fracture risk factors and does not require computer access
Any T-score ≤-2.5 at spine, total hip, or femoral neck indicates at least moderate risk regardless of age
Fragility fracture history elevates risk by one category (low to moderate, moderate to high)
Glucocorticoid use elevates risk by one category
Both fragility fracture AND glucocorticoid use indicates high risk regardless of BMD
Tool is primarily validated for Canadian population and may not generalize to other ethnicities
